translated: Birth Stories🔽The Fives
The Half
The Little Archer Birth Story
“Having taken all your goods,
you’re crossing over to the other side, brahmin.
Come back quickly and soon,

analyzed: tārehi dānitaḥ  a santhutam mam cira santhutena
translated: and deliver me too, generous one.”
“You’ve never met me before, but you’re always meeting with the one who’s permanent and eternal.
You should meet with someone else,
for I’m going far away from here.”
“You’re making a little hut of gum and resin,
laughing to yourself.
There’s no dancing or singing here,
or any well-practiced clapping.
At the wrong time, good lady,
why are you laughing, beautiful one?”
“Jackal, you’re a fool, unintelligent,
unwise, and conceited.
You’ve lost your fish and meat,
and you’re sighing like a pauper.”
“It’s easy to see the faults of others,
but it’s hard to see one’s own.
You’ve lost your husband and lover,

analyzed: maññe tvaññā iva jhāyasi  evam etam miga rāja
translated: and I think you’re sighing all by yourself.”🔽“It’s just as you say, king of deer,
you jackal.
But I’ll go from here,
and I’ll be obedient to my husband.”
“You who stole the clay bowl,
you must also steal the bronze bowl;
And the evil you have done,
you will do again.”
The Short Story of the Archer, the Fourth.
